info.author: Erik Max Francis
classifiers: License :: OSI Approved :: GNU General Public License (GPL)
Topic :: Software Development :: Libraries :: Python Modules
info.description:
BOTEC is intended as a simple but useful calculator to assist with making
astrophysical, orbital mechanics, and space navigation calculations. As the
origin of the acronym applies, BOTEC is more of a "back-of-the-envelope
calculator" rather than an industrial-strength calculator, although this may
change in the future.

BOTEC is primarily intended for people familiar with physics and Python, and as
such is unlikely to be useful to the average enduser. BOTEC really consists of
two parts: The BOTEC software, which knows what to do with the data, and the
Solar System data itself, which is represented in a large data file (a Python
pickle, actually). This is deliberately modularized so that the Solar System
data BOTEC uses can be updated independently of thet software, and also that
alternative data files (e.g., hypothetical stellar systems for fictional
purposes) can be supported.

All values are strictly in SI units.
info.keywords: physics, astronomy, astrophysics, orbital mechanics, course plotting, Hohmann transfer
info.name: BOTEC
info.summary: A simple astrophysics and orbital mechanics simulator
info.html_description:
BOTEC is intended as a simple but useful calculator to assist with making astrophysical, orbital mechanics, and space navigation calculations. As the origin of the acronym applies, BOTEC is more of a “back-of-the-envelope calculator” rather than an industrial-strength calculator, although this may change in the future.

BOTEC is primarily intended for people familiar with physics and Python, and as such is unlikely to be useful to the average enduser. BOTEC really consists of two parts: The BOTEC software, which knows what to do with the data, and the Solar System data itself, which is represented in a large data file (a Python pickle, actually). This is deliberately modularized so that the Solar System data BOTEC uses can be updated independently of thet software, and also that alternative data files (e.g., hypothetical stellar systems for fictional purposes) can be supported.

All values are strictly in SI units.
